questions.text: What is the duration of the longer MDR-TB regimen?
questions.explanation:
Indications

Additional resistance (e.g., fluoroquinolones)

Severe pulmonary/extrapulmonary disease

Previous treatment with second-line drugs

Recommended Drugs (Group A)

Bedaquiline

Linezolid

Fluoroquinolone (levofloxacin or moxifloxacin)

Additional Drugs

(Group B)

Clofazimine

Cycloserine

Alternative Drugs

(Group C)

Used to replace Group A or B agents when necessary

Choice based on drug susceptibility testing, resistance levels, previous use, and patient tolerance

Duration

18–20 months or more, depending on the patient's response

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a painless swelling in the posterior cervical lymph nodes. There are no systemic symptoms, and a fine-needle aspiration biopsy reveals granulomatous lesions without acid-fast bacilli (AFBs). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Lymph Node TB (Tuberculous Lymphadenitis)

Most common extrapulmonary TB presentation.

Risk Groups

HIV-positive individuals, children, and non-Caucasian women.

Causative Organism

Previously M. bovis; now mainly M. tuberculosis.

Clinical Presentation
  • Painless swelling in lymph nodes, usually posterior cervical or supraclavicular (historically called scrofula).
  • Early disease: Discrete nodes
  • Advanced disease: Matted, nontender mass, possible fistula draining caseous material.
  • Pulmonary disease in <50% of cases.
  • Systemic symptoms are uncommon except in HIV-positive patients.
  • Non-specific reaction → Matting → Cold Abscess → Collar stud abscess → Sinus formation

Diagnosis
  • Fine-needle aspiration biopsy (80% yield) or surgical excision biopsy.
  • Granulomatous lesions may or may not contain AFBs.
  • Cultures are positive in 70–80% of cases.
  • HIV-positive patients: Poorly organized or absent granulomas; higher bacterial loads increase diagnostic yield.

Differential Diagnosis
  • Infectious diseases
  • Lymphomas
  • Metastatic carcinomas
  • Rare disorders: Kikuchi’s disease, Kimura’s disease, Castleman’s disease.

Extrapulmonary TB Sites (Descending Order of Frequency)
  1. Lymph nodes
  2. Pleura
  3. Genitourinary tract
  4. Bones and joints
  5. Meninges
  6. Peritoneum
  7. Pericardium

Prevalence of Extrapulmonary TB
  • More common in settings with high HIV prevalence due to hematogenous spread.
  • Any organ may be affected, especially in HIV-positive individuals

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with fever, pleuritic chest pain, and dyspnea. Physical examination revealed dullness to percussion and absent breath sounds on the left side. Chest X-ray shows a left-sided pleural effusion. Thoracentesis reveals straw-coloured fluid with a protein concentration of 5 g/dL and a WBC count of 1500/μL with lymphocyte predominance. The acid-fast bacilli (AFB) smear is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Pleural TB
 

Pleural Effusion Characteristics
  • Isolated Pleural Effusion: Recent primary TB infection.
  • Hypersensitivity to mycobacterial antigens.
  • Can occur due to contiguous parenchymal spread in postprimary TB.
  • Asymptomatic: Small effusion, resolves spontaneously.
  • Symptomatic: Larger effusion causes fever, pleuritic chest pain, and dyspnea.

Physical Exam Findings
  • Dullness to percussion.
  • Absence of breath sounds.

CXR Findings
  • Reveals pleural effusion.
  • Parenchymal lesions in up to one-third of cases.

Thoracentesis Findings
  • Fluid Color: Straw-colored (sometimes hemorrhagic).
  • Exudate: Protein concentration ~4-6 g/dL (>50% of serum).
  • Glucose: Normal to low.
  • pH: ~7.3 (occasionally <7.2).
  • WBC: 500–6000/μL (lymphocyte predominance in later stages).
  • Mesothelial Cells: Rare or absent.

AFB (Acid-Fast Bacilli)
  • Rarely seen on direct smear.
  • Cultures may be negative, especially in early cases.

Additional Diagnostic Tests
  • Adenosine Deaminase: Useful for screening; low values exclude TB.
  • IFN-γ: Measured directly or through T-cell stimulation.
  • Pleural Biopsy: Preferred for diagnosis; reveals granulomas or positive culture in up to 80% of cases.
  • Xpert MTB/RIF Assay: 75% positivity in pleural biopsy; fluid testing not recommended.

Treatment
  • Chemotherapy: Rapid response, spontaneous resolution possible.
  • Glucocorticoids: May reduce fever/chest pain but have unproven benefits.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a 2-week history of headaches, low-grade fever, irritability, and confusion. On examination, he has neck stiffness and cranial nerve VI palsy. Lumbar puncture reveals a CSF leukocyte count of 800/μL (lymphocyte predominance), protein of 400 mg/dL, and low glucose. AFB smear is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
TB Meningitis

Pathophysiology
  • Tuberculous Meningitis results from hematogenous spread of primary or postprimary TB or rupture of a subependymal tubercle into the subarachnoid space.

Onset

Evolves over 1–2 weeks, slower than bacterial meningitis.

Symptoms
  • Early Symptoms
    • Headache, mild mental changes, low-grade fever, malaise, anorexia, irritability over several weeks.
  • Advanced Symptoms
    • Severe headache, confusion, lethargy, altered sensorium, neck rigidity, cranial nerve palsies (especially ocular). Can progress to coma, hydrocephalus, and intracranial hypertension.

Lumbar Puncture Findings (CSF)
  • High leukocyte count (up to 1000/μL), typically lymphocyte predominance
  • Protein: 1–8 g/L (100–800 mg/dL)
  • Low glucose concentration
  • AFB is rarely seen; repeated lumbar punctures increase yield.
  • CSF culture diagnostic in up to 80% (gold standard).

Xpert MTB/RIF Assay
  • Sensitivity up to 80%.
  • A negative result does not exclude TB.

Imaging
  • CT, MRI: Shows hydrocephalus and enhancement of basal cisterns or ependyma.
 

Basal cistern enhancement

  • In >50% of cases, old pulmonary lesions or military pattern on CXR.

Treatment

Immediate treatment with positive Xpert MTB/RIF.

  • Chemotherapy is effective but neurologic sequelae occur in 25% of cases, especially with delayed diagnosis.
  • Glucocorticoid Therapy
    • Dexamethasone reduces mortality and severe disability but may not prevent neurological sequelae.
    • Regimen: 0.4 mg/kg/day IV, tapering weekly, followed by oral tapering. WHO recommends tapering over 6–8 weeks.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with chronic back pain, fatigue, and weight loss. MRI of the spine reveals destruction of the lower thoracic vertebrae with a paravertebral abscess tracking into the psoas muscle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Spinal TB (Pott’s Disease)

Involves lower thoracic and upper lumbar vertebrae in adults; and upper thoracic spine in children.

Lesions spread to adjacent vertebrae and intervertebral disks.

Advanced Disease
  • Collapse of vertebrae leads to kyphosis (gibbus deformity).
  • Paravertebral cold abscesses:
    • Upper spine: Abscess may penetrate the chest wall as a soft tissue mass.
    • Lower spine: May track to the inguinal region or form a psoas abscess.

Diagnosis of Spinal TB
  • Imaging (CT/MRI): Shows characteristic lesions, suggesting TB aetiology.
  • Differential Diagnosis: Includes tumours and infections like pyogenic bacterial osteomyelitis.
  • Confirmation: Aspiration or biopsy confirms TB via positive cultures and typical histology.

Complications
  • Paraplegia: Due to abscess or spinal cord compression; requires emergency drainage if caused by a large abscess.

TB of Hip and Knee Joints
  • Hip TB: Affects the head of the femur, causing pain.
  • Knee TB: Causes pain and swelling.
  • If untreated, joint destruction can occur.

Diagnosis of Joint TB
  • Synovial Fluid: Thick with high protein concentration and variable cell count.
  • Synovial Fluid Culture: Often positive, but synovial biopsy and tissue culture may be required.

Treatment
  • Chemotherapy: Effective for most cases.
  • Surgery: This may be needed in severe cases with joint or vertebral destruction.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a history of pelvic pain, menstrual irregularities, and frequent urination over the past few months. She reports that her symptoms have worsened and she experiences occasional hematuria. Urinalysis shows pyuria, but urine cultures are negative. A pelvic ultrasound reveals abnormalities in the fallopian tubes. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: Can be either B or C

questions.explanation:
Genitourinary Tuberculosis (TB)

Pathophysiology
  • Can affect any part of the genitourinary tract. Symptoms often appear late, after destructive kidney lesions have developed.

Symptoms
  • Urinary Symptoms: Frequency, dysuria, nocturia, hematuria
  • Other Symptoms: Abdominal or flank pain
  • Asymptomatic: Some patients are asymptomatic, leading to delayed diagnosis and irreversible organ damage.

Genital TB (Women)
  • It affects fallopian tubes and endometrium, causing infertility, pelvic pain, and menstrual abnormalities.
  • Diagnosis via biopsy or culture from dilation and curettage.

Genital TB (Men)
  • It affects epididymis (a tender mass that may drain via the fistula); orchitis and prostatitis may also occur.
  • In 50% of cases, urinary tract involvement is also present.

Diagnosis
  • CXR: Up to 75% show abnormalities suggesting past or concurrent pulmonary TB.
  • Urinalysis: Abnormal in 90% of cases (pyuria, hematuria). Culture-negative pyuria in acidic urine is a key clue.
  • Imaging: IV pyelography, abdominal CT, or MRI show deformities, obstructions, calcifications, and ureteral strictures.
  • Urine Culture: Three-morning urine specimens confirm diagnosis in nearly 90% of cases.

Complications
  • Ureteral Strictures: Can cause hydronephrosis, renal damage, and renal failure.

Treatment
  • Responds well to chemotherapy.

Gastrointestinal Tuberculosis

Mechanisms of Infection
  • Swallowing of sputum with direct seeding.
  • Hematogenous spread.
  • Ingestion of contaminated bovine milk (common in developing areas).

Common sites of infection
  • Terminal ileum and cecum.

Symptoms
  • Abdominal: Pain (similar to appendicitis), swelling, obstruction, hematochezia, palpable abdominal mass.
  • Systemic: Fever, weight loss, anorexia, night sweats.
  • Complications: Ulcerations and fistulae (mimicking Crohn’s disease); anal fistula suggests rectal TB.

Diagnosis

  • Surgery is required to obtain histologic and culture specimens intraoperatively.
  • Differential Diagnosis: Difficult to distinguish from Crohn’s disease.

Tuberculous Peritonitis

Pathophysiology
  • Results from the direct spread of tubercle bacilli from ruptured lymph nodes or intra-abdominal organs (e.g., genital TB in women), or hematogenous spread.

Symptoms
  • Abdominal: Nonspecific abdominal pain, ascites.
  • Systemic: Fever.
  • Complication: Coexistence with cirrhosis complicates diagnosis.

Diagnosis
  • Paracentesis: Reveals exudative fluid with high protein content and lymphocytic leukocytosis (neutrophils may predominate at times).
  • Direct Smear/Culture: Low yield; culturing large volumes of ascitic fluid may improve results.
  • Peritoneal Biopsy: Typically needed for diagnosis, best obtained via laparoscopy.

Treatment
  • Surgical intervention may be required for diagnosis and management in many cases.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents with fever and pleuritic chest pain. Chest X-ray shows a small calcified lesion in the lower right lung and enlarged hilar lymph nodes. He also has a rash on his legs resembling erythema nodosum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Primary TB - Pathophysiology

Primary pulmonary TB occurs shortly after initial TB infection; common in children in high-transmission areas. May be asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic.

Common Symptoms
  • Fever
  • Occasionally, pleuritic chest pain
  • Skin manifestations: erythema nodosum (legs) or phlyctenular conjunctivitis

Pathology
  • Primary Lesion (Ghon Focus): The initial lesion typically forms in the middle or lower lung zones, often peripheral with transient hilar/paratracheal lymphadenopathy.
  • Ghon Complex: Combination of Ghon focus, pleural reaction, and regional lymphadenopathy; may heal and calcify over time. The calcified lesion is called Ranke complex.

Disease Progression
  • In Immunocompromised Individuals (e.g., young children, HIV+ patients):
  • Lesion enlargement with potential necrosis and cavitation (progressive primary TB).
  • Pleural Effusion: Bacilli may penetrate pleural space from subpleural focus; seen in up to two-thirds of severe cases.

Lymphatic Spread
  • Lymphadenopathy: Enlarged hilar/paratracheal lymph nodes can compress bronchi, causing:
  • Bronchial obstruction and lung collapse
  • Partial obstruction with wheezing
  • Segmental/lobar hyperinflation (ball-valve effect).
  • Lymph node rupture may lead to necrotic pneumonia and cavitation in distal airways.

Complications
  • Bronchiectasis: May develop in areas affected by progressive caseating pneumonia.
  • Dissemination: Hematogenous spread can lead to:
  • Miliary Disease: Multiple granulomatous lesions in organs.
  • TB Meningitis: Particularly in young children and immunocompromised individuals.

questions.text: Which finding is not typically present in primary tuberculosis?
questions.explanation:
Hilar lymphadenopathy

Common in primary TB, especially in children. Enlarged lymph nodes near the lung hilum are often seen on imaging.

Perihilar infiltrate

Frequently observed; represents primary infection near the hilum and surrounding lung tissue.

perihilar infiltrates.png" data-author="" data-hash="9398" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/a4uh1Bb6kZ9aca0PS2pv1744375310.png" />

Pleural effusion

Present in cases of primary TB, especially in adolescents and young adults, due to pleural inflammation.

Cavity

Cavitary lesions are more characteristic of reactivation (post-primary) TB rather than primary TB.

Snowstorm appearance

This refers to miliary TB, which shows numerous tiny nodules scattered throughout the lungs. It’s seen in disseminated TB rather than in localized primary TB.

Ghon Complex
  • Consists of a combination of a Ghon focus (a primary granulomatous lesion in the lung) and involved regional lymph nodes (usually hilar lymph nodes).
  • Located in the lower part of the upper lobe or the upper part of the lower lobe of the lung.

questions.text: In the pathophysiology of postprimary tuberculosis, which of the following immunological events is most critical for the development of cavitary lesions in the lung apices and how does it contribute to tissue destruction?

options.label: A
options.text: Activation of B cells leads to antibody production, which facilitates phagocytosis of M. tuberculosis.

options.label: B
options.text: Release of IL-4 and IL-10 from T-helper cells, promoting a Th2 response that leads to fibrosis and walling off of the infection.

options.label: C
options.text: Secretion of TNF-α and IFN-γ by activated T cells, resulting in macrophage activation and the subsequent formation of caseous necrosis.

options.label: D
options.text: Induction of a robust innate immune response mediated by neutrophils, resulting in rapid clearance of bacteria and prevention of necrosis.

questions.correct_answer: C. Secretion of TNF-α and IFN-γ by activated T cells, resulting in macrophage activation and the subsequent formation of caseous necrosis.
questions.explanation:
Reactivation of Latent Infection
  • After the primary infection, TB bacilli can become encapsulated within granulomas formed in the lungs or lymph nodes. These granulomas help contain the infection but do not eliminate it.
  • The bacteria can remain dormant for years in this latent state. Reactivation occurs when the host's immune response is weakened, which can be due to factors such as immunosuppressive conditions (HIV, diabetes, malnutrition)

Immune Response
  • Upon reactivation, a cell-mediated immune response is triggered, primarily involving T lymphocytes (CD4+ and CD8+ T cells).
  • Activated T cells release cytokines like interferon-gamma (IFN-γ), which activates macrophages, enhancing their ability to kill intracellular bacteria.
  • Despite this response, the immune system may fail to contain the bacteria, leading to continued replication.

Granuloma Formation and Caseous Necrosis
  • The reactivated bacilli can cause caseous necrosis within the granulomas, characterised by the destruction of lung tissue and the formation of a necrotic centre.
  • This necrosis leads to the formation of cavitary lesions, especially in the lung apices, where oxygen levels are higher, favouring the growth of M. tuberculosis.

Cavitation
  • Occurs in the apices of the lungs or apical segments of the lower lobes.
  • As the necrotic tissue liquefies, cavities develop in the lung parenchyma. These cavities provide a nutrient-rich environment for the bacteria, allowing them to proliferate.
  • The presence of cavitary lesions and ongoing inflammation can lead to the destruction of lung tissue and impairment of lung function.
  • In some cases, the infection can spread hematogenously, leading to extrapulmonary TB, affecting other organs like the kidneys, bones, and central nervous system.

questions.text: Which of the following matches the type of tuberculosis focus with its correct location? Type of TB Focus Location 1. Assman Focus a. Subpleural 2. Ghon Focus b. Infraclavicular 3. Puhl Lesion c. Supraclavicular 4. Rich Focus d. Brain
questions.explanation:
Type of TB

Focus Location

Assman Focus

Infraclavicular

Ghon Focus

Subpleural

Puhl Lesion

Supraclavicular

Rich Focus

Brain

Focus/Lesion

Location

Ghon Focus
  • Location: Lower part of the upper lobe or upper part of the lower lobe of the lung, typically subpleural.
  • The initial area of infection in primary TB appears as a granulomatous lesion. When combined with lymph node involvement, it forms the Ghon complex.

Simon Focus
  • Location: Apices of the lungs.
  • A small nodular lesion forms in the lung apices due to the reactivation of dormant TB bacteria.

Assmann Focus
  • Location: Infraclavicular
  • It is prone to cavitation, leading to potential bacterial spread and transmission.

Weigert Focus
  • Location: In the lung tissue near blood vessels.
  • Occurs due to hematogenous (blood-borne) spread of TB, creating lesions along the vascular pathways. Weigart focus is often seen in miliary or disseminated TB.

Rich Focus
  • Location: Brain or meninges.
  • A site of TB infection within the central nervous system, which can rupture, leading to tuberculous meningitis.

Ranke Complex
  • Location: Typically in the lung apices with calcified lymph nodes in the hilum.
  • The Ranke complex consists of a calcified Ghon focus and involved lymph nodes, indicating old, inactive TB.

Puhl lesion

  • Location: Most commonly found in the supraclavicular region, which is significant as this location can indicate the spread of TB from the lungs or other primary sites of infection.

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of Interferon-gamma release assays (IGRAs) to tuberculosis?

options.label: D
options.text: To assess the severity of lung disease

questions.correct_answer: B. To diagnose latent TB infection

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the principle behind the LAMP test?

options.label: B
options.text: Isothermal amplification of DNA at a constant temperature

questions.correct_answer: B. Isothermal amplification of DNA at a constant temperature
questions.explanation:
Investigations

Purpose

Advantages

Limitations

Sputum smear

Initial screening for pulmonary TB.

Samples are stained using the Ziehl-Neelsen method or Auramine-O stain to visualize acid-fast bacilli (AFB) under a microscope.

Quick and inexpensive. Can provide results within a few hours.

Low sensitivity, especially in cases of extrapulmonary TB or in patients with HIV.

Cannot differentiate between Mycobacterium tuberculosis and non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM).

Culture Methods

Confirm the diagnosis of TB and assess drug susceptibility.

Solid Media: Sputum is inoculated onto solid culture media like Löwenstein-Jensen or Middlebrook agar.

Liquid Media: Automated systems like BACTEC or MGIT are used to detect growth faster.

The gold standard for TB diagnosis.

Allows for drug susceptibility testing.

Time-consuming; results can take weeks.

Requires specialized laboratory facilities.

Xpert MTB/RIF

Detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance.

Method:

A cartridge-based system that performs nucleic acid amplification (NAAT).

Sputum or other specimens are processed directly in the cartridge.

Rapid results (within 2 hours).

High sensitivity and specificity.

Simultaneously detects rifampicin resistance.

More expensive than smear microscopy.

Does not provide full drug susceptibility testing.

LAMP (Loop-Mediated Isothermal Amplification)

Detects DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Method:

Amplifies DNA at a constant temperature without the need for thermal cycling.

Sputum or other specimens are used.

Rapid results (within 1-2 hours).

High specificity and sensitivity.

Can be performed at the point of care.

Used for patients with HIV with CD4+ counts of less than 100 cells/μL irrespective of signs and symptoms of TB.

Less widely available than PCR-based tests.

Cannot detect drug resistance directly.

TrueNat

Point-of-care test for TB detection.

Method:

Uses a micro-PCR technology to amplify DNA.

Results are available within 60 minutes.


 

Portable and easy to use in peripheral health facilities.

Provides results quickly, facilitating immediate treatment decisions.

  

Line Probe Assay (LPA)

Detects TB and drug resistance (rifampicin and isoniazid).

Method:

Sputum samples are processed, and DNA is extracted.

Amplified DNA is hybridized to specific probes on a membrane strip.

Rapid results (within 1-2 days).

Can detect multiple mutations associated with drug resistance.

Requires a laboratory setup and trained personnel.

Not suitable for all strains of TB.

RFLP

IS6110 restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis is widely used for molecular epidemiological studies of tuberculosis. Restriction enzymes Nru I, EcoN I, Pst I, and Pvu II were used to analyze IS6110 fingerprints in Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains H37Rv (virulent) and H37Ra (avirulent).

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with advanced HIV infection (CD4 count of 50 cells/mm³) is diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) and started on anti-tuberculosis treatment. Two weeks later, he initiated antiretroviral therapy (ART). After 3 weeks on ART, he returns to the clinic complaining of worsening cough, fever and night sweats. Physical examination reveals enlarged cervical lymph nodes and increased lung crackles on auscultation. His viral load has dropped significantly, but his CD4 count remains low. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Match the drugs used in the initial treatment of tuberculosis with their dosage. Drugs Dosage (mg/kg) a.Isoniazid i.10 b.Rifampicin ii.15 c.Pyrazinamide iii.5 d.Ethambutol iv.25
questions.explanation:
Drug

Dose

Mechanism of action

Isoniazid

5 mg/kg

Inhibiting the biosynthesis of mycolic acid.

Rifampicin

10 mg/kg

Inhibiting DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, which further inhibits bacterial protein synthesis and transcription.

Pyrazinamide

25 mg/kg

Inhibiting trans-translation and possibly coenzyme A synthesis is needed for the bacteria to survive.

Ethambutol

15 mg/kg

Inhibits the enzyme arabinosyltransferases and prevents the biosynthesis of the mycobacterial cell wall.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the shorter MDR-TB regimen?
questions.explanation:
Indications

MDR-TB patients without extensive pulmonary or severe extrapulmonary disease

No history of second-line drug use

No fluoroquinolone resistance

Recommended Drugs

6 months of bedaquiline, levofloxacin (or moxifloxacin) (Option A ruled out), ethionamide, ethambutol, pyrazinamide, high-dose isoniazid (Option D), clofazimine

Followed by 5 months of levofloxacin (or moxifloxacin), clofazimine(Option B ruled out), pyrazinamide, and ethambutol (Option C ruled out)

Treatment Approach

Prioritize outpatient care with adequate support when stable

Hospitalization if necessary

Respiratory infection control is essential

Common sites of infection

Terminal ileum and cecum.
